hProperties.aria-label: graphql types for each type of node permalink

children.value: GraphQL Types for each type of node
When running a GraphQL query, there are a variety of fields that you will want to query. Let’s take an example, say we have the below query:

{
  file( relativePath: {  eq: `blogs/my-blog.md` } ) {
    childMarkdownRemark {
      frontmatter: {
        title
      }
    }
  }
}
When GraphQL runs, it will query all
nodes by their relativePath and return the first node that satisfies that query. Then, it will filter down the fields to return by the inner expression. I.e
. The building of the query arguments is covered by the
doc. This section instead explains how the inner filter schema is generated (it must be generated before input filters are inferred).
ran and created a bunch of
nodes. Then, different transformers react via
There are 3 categories of node fields that we can query.

hProperties.aria-label: fields on the created node object eg permalink

children.value: Fields on the created node object. E.g

node {
  relativePath,
  extension,
  size,
  accessTime
}

node {
  childMarkdownRemark,
  childrenPostsJson,
  children,
  parent
}

node {
  publicURL
}
Each of these categories of fields is created in a different way, explained below.
The Gatsby term for the GraphQLObjectType for a unique node type, is
. GraphQLObjectTypes are simply objects that define the type name and fields. The field definitions are created by the

An important thing to note is that all gqlTypes are created before their fields are inferred. This allows fields to be of types that haven’t yet been created due to their order of compilation. This is accomplished by the use of
The first step in inferring GraphQL Fields is to generate an
. It is the result of merging all fields of all nodes of the type in question. This
will therefore contain all potential field names and values, which allows us to infer each field’s types. The logic to create it is in
With the exampleValue in hand, we can use each of its key/values to infer the Type’s fields (broken down by the 3 categories above).

hProperties.aria-label: fields on the created node object permalink

children.value: Fields on the created node object

If the foreign key value is an array of IDs, then instead of returning a Field declaration for a single field, we return a

hProperties.aria-label: plain object or value field permalink

children.value: If the field was not handled as a mapping or foreign key reference, then it must be a normal every day field. E.g a scalar, string, or plain object. These cases are handled by
The core of this step creates a GraphQL Field object, where the type is inferred directly via the result of
. Since these are simple values, resolvers are not defined (graphql-js takes care of that for us).
If however, the value is an object or array, we recurse, using
In addition, Gatsby creates custom GraphQL types for
). If the value of our field is a string that looks like a filename or a date (handled by
functions), then we return the appropariate custom type.
type example. There are many transformer plugins that implement
children that are of their own type. E.g
Gatsby stores these children in redux as IDs in the parent’s
field. And then stores those child nodes as full redux nodes themselves (see
for more). E.g for a File node with two children, it will be stored in the redux

{
  `id1`: { type: `File`, children: [`id2`, `id3`], ...other_fields },
  `id2`: { type: `markdownRemark`, ...other_fields },
  `id3`: { type: `postsJson`, ...other_fields }
}

An important note here is that we do not store a distinct collection of each type of child. Rather we store a single collection that they’re all packed into. The benefit of this is that we can easily create a
field that returns all children, regardless of type. The downside is that the creation of fields such as
is more complicated. This is what
Another convenience Gatsby provides is the ability to query a node’s
, depending on whether a parent node has 1 or more children of that type.
will iterate over the distinct types of its children, and create their fields. Let’s say one of these child types is
. Let’s assume there is only one
. Now, we must create its graphql Resolver.
resolve(node, args, context, info)
The resolve function will be called when we are running queries for our pages. A query might look like:

query {
  file( relativePath { eq: "blog/my-blog.md" } ) {
    childMarkdownRemark { html }
  }
}
, we take the node we’re resolving, and filter over all of its
until we find one of type
is a collection of IDs. So as part of this, we lookup the node by ID in redux too.

But before we return from the resolve function, remember that we might be running this query within the context of a page. If that’s the case, then whenever the node changes, the page will need to be rerendered. To record that fact, we call call
with the node ID and the page, which is a field in the
object in the resolve function signature.
When a node is created as a child of some node (parent), that fact is stored in the child’s
field. The value of which is the ID of the parent. The
for this field looks up the parent by that ID in redux and returns it. It also creates a
, to record that the page being queried depends on the parent node.
These are fields created by plugins that implement the
API. These plugins return full GraphQL Field declarations, complete with type and resolve functions.
, if a string field value looks like a file path, then we infer
as the field’s type. The creation of this type occurs in
. It is called just after we have created the GqlType for
It creates a new GraphQL Field Config whose type is the just created
GqlType, and whose resolver converts a string into a File object. Here’s how it works:
file that has been sourced (of type
transformer creates a child node (of type

;[
  {
    id: "1685001452849004065",
    text: "Venice is 👌",
    image: "images/BdiU-TTFP4h.jpg",
  },
]
Notice that the image value looks like a file. Therefore, we’d like to query it as if it were a file, and get its relativePath, accessTime, etc.

{
  postsJson(id: { eq: "1685001452849004065" }) {
    image {
      relativePath
      accessTime
    }
  }
}
takes care of this. It gets the value (
). It then looks up this node’s root NodeID via
file. It creates a new filename by concatenating the field value onto the parent node’s directory.
And then finally it searches redux for the first
node whose path matches this one. This is our proper resolved node. We’re done!
